BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In little used terrain a moderate avalanche danger will persist in some regions.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh snow and in particular the wind slabs can still be released in some cases in particular on north to east to southeast facing aspects and generally at intermediate and high altitudes. These are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas and generally at elevated altitudes.
In these regions only isolated mostly small moist and wet avalanches are possible as the temperature drops.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The new snow of last week has bonded quite well with the old snowpack in all aspects. The weather conditions gave rise to favourable bonding of the snowpack over a wide area. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
Sunny slopes: As a consequence of falling temperatures and solar radiation the snowpack will consolidate during the next few days.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The meteorological conditions will facilitate a slow strengthening of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of warming, the natural avalanche activity will gradually increase.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be quite good. As a consequence of warming during the day, the likelihood of natural wet avalanches being released will increase gradually in particular on steep southeast and southwest facing slopes at intermediate altitudes. The sometimes large wind slabs of last week must be evaluated with care and prudence in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 3000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise from late morning to a loss of strength within the snowpack over a wide area in particular on steep sunny slopes above approximately 1600 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of warming, the natural avalanche activity will gradually increase.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be quite good. As a consequence of warming during the day, the likelihood of natural wet avalanches being released will increase gradually in particular on steep southeast and southwest facing slopes at intermediate altitudes. The sometimes large wind slabs of last week must be evaluated with care and prudence in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 3000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise from late morning to a loss of strength within the snowpack over a wide area in particular on steep sunny slopes above approximately 1600 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
The weather will be mild over a wide area.
As the moisture increases the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As the day progresses in particular on sunny slopes there will be a gradual increase in the danger of moist and wet avalanches. Gliding avalanches can also occur.
As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of avalanches being released will increase also on steep north facing slopes above approximately 1800 m. Some medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large avalanches are possible. This applies in particular in case of a large load. Backcountry tours should be concluded early.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The weather conditions as the day progresses will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack.
The new snow of recent weeks is loosely bonded on shady slopes above approximately 1800 m. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
The weather will be mild.
Over a wide area a mostly overcast night.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In extremely steep terrain more moist and wet avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A partly overcast night. In particular intermediate altitudes: The danger of moist and wet avalanches will already exist in the early morning.
As a consequence of warming during the day there will be an additional increase in the danger of moist and wet avalanches, in particular at the base of rock walls. As a consequence of solar radiation small and medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2700 m. This applies in particular on very steep sunny slopes.

The visible wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases, especially at their margins. These avalanche prone locations are rather rare and are easy to recognise. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas above approximately 2600 m and in extremely steep terrain. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying.
The new snow of last week has settled to a large extent in particular on steep sunny slopes. The new snow and wind slabs have bonded quite well with the old snowpack in particular on sunny slopes.
The weather conditions fostered a gradual strengthening of the snowpack. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to moistening of the snowpack in some cases in particular on very steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In some localities light snowfall: The avalanche danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Field observations have shown good snowpack stability.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The mostly small wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, but mostly only by large additional loads,. This applies in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls in particular at intermediate and high altitudes.
Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised in particular in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls.
In these regions only isolated mostly small moist and wet avalanches are possible as the temperature drops.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The weather conditions gave rise to favourable bonding of the snowpack over a wide area.
In isolated cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on old snow containing large grains. This applies especially on shady slopes.
Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise from early morning to increasing moistening of the snowpack in some places on sunny slopes.
Sunny slopes: As a consequence of falling temperatures and solar radiation the snowpack will consolidate.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The danger of moist avalanches will increase during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: On Friday it will be very warm over a wide area. The danger of wet and gliding avalanches will increase during the day. Below approximately 2600 m small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible. The sometimes strong wind has transported some snow. The wind slabs have formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in the high Alpine regions. The fresh wind slabs can be released by small loads. Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released by winter sport participants in particular on very steep northwest, north and northeast facing slopes. Weak layers in the old snowpack necessitate caution.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The new snow of the last few days is very loosely bonded in particular on shady slopes above approximately 2100 m. The snowpack is largely stable; its surface consists of loosely bonded snow. The high temperatures as the day progresses will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack in particular on very steep sunny slopes. Weak layers exist in the snowpack in particular on northwest, north and northeast facing slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Avalanches can in isolated cases be released by small loads. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep shady slopes. Avalanches can penetrate even deep layers and reach medium size in isolated cases.

As a consequence of warming during the day only isolated wet loose snow slides are to be expected below approximately 2600 m. This applies in particular on extremely steep sunny slopes.

Hardly any more gliding avalanches are to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In its middle, the snowpack is weak in some cases. Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in isolated cases in particular on steep shady slopes.

As a consequence of falling temperatures and low relative humidity a crust formed on the surface during the night. The spring-like weather conditions as the day progresses will give rise to slight softening of the snowpack in particular on extremely steep sunny slopes. These conditions will cause a slight weakening of the near-surface layers as the day progresses.

At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche conditions are quite safe.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in isolated cases in particular on steep shady slopes. As the day progresses more moist and wet snow slides are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Avalanches can penetrate even deep layers and reach medium size in isolated cases.
As a consequence of warming during the day individual wet loose snow slides are possible below approximately 2600 m. This applies especially on west, south and southeast facing slopes. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of falling temperatures and low relative humidity a crust formed on the surface during the night. In its middle, the snowpack is weak in some cases and its surface has a crust that is barely capable of bearing a load. Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in isolated cases.
Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to softening of the snowpack in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep shady slopes. Small avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will be generally well bonded.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
The weather will be mild.
Over a wide area a mostly overcast night.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Currently there are favourable conditions generally.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Wind slabs can be released in isolated cases in particular on extremely steep shady slopes. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain, in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. Mostly avalanches are small. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.

Only isolated wet loose snow slides are possible below approximately 2600 m. Hardly any more gliding avalanches are to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In near-surface layers, there are multiple melt-freeze crusts sandwiches with faceted layers in between. These layers can still be occasionally triggered, although the thickness of the slab is usually thin. Towards its base, the snowpack is stable.

At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche conditions are quite safe.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As the day progresses wet snow slides and avalanches are to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation individual small moist snow slides and avalanches are possible. This applies in particular on steep sunny slopes. Mostly avalanches are only small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The spring-like weather conditions as the day progresses will give rise to increasing softening of the snowpack over a wide area. Wind slabs are now only very rarely prone to triggering.
At low and intermediate altitudes a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche conditions are quite safe.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs are in isolated cases prone to triggering.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Wind slabs can be released in isolated cases in particular on extremely steep shady slopes. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain, in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. Mostly avalanches are small. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.

Only isolated gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow will fall, in particular above approximately 2000 m. In near-surface layers, there are multiple melt-freeze crusts sandwiches with faceted layers in between. These layers can still be occasionally triggered, although the thickness of the slab is usually thin. Towards its base, the snowpack is stable.

At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche conditions are quite safe.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The avalanche conditions are quite safe.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of warming during the day hardly any more wet loose snow slides are to be expected.

Wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads, on extremely steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m, especially adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas. Avalanches are only small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The spring-like weather conditions as the day progresses will give rise to increasing softening of the snowpack over a wide area.

Wind slabs are now only very rarely prone to triggering.

At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is now lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche conditions are quite safe.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Only isolated mostly small avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The avalanche prone locations are rather rare and are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. From the late morning as a consequence of solar radiation there will be only a slight increase in the danger of dry and moist avalanches, especially on very steep sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes, as well as on wind-loaded slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will be generally well bonded. A clear night will be followed in the early morning by quite favourable conditions mostly. Especially sunny slopes: The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust and will soften during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh and older wind slabs at high altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Individual mostly small avalanches are possible above approximately 1800 m. This applies especially in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack remains subject to considerable local variations. At high altitude only a little snow is lying. At high altitude mostly small wind slabs formed. In gullies and bowls the wind slabs are larger.
